pr_title: [BEAM-10691] Use FlinkStateInternals#addWatermarkHoldUsage for timer output timestamp

timeline.bodyText: This is very expensive in terms of memory.
timeline.author: mxm

replies.bodyText: Agree, that's why I don't generally like this solution and would like to come up with different one.
replies.author: je-ik

timeline.bodyText: IMHO there is no need to store the timer id here.
timeline.author: mxm

replies.bodyText: It should not. But in some cases, a timer output timestamp seems to appear in the queue twice (for the same timer) and removed only once, which causes the pipeline to get stuck.
replies.author: je-ik

replies.bodyText:
Duplicates are ok. If we have multiple timers set with different ids or even for the same keys, duplicates are expected. We could use a TreeMap instead of a PriorityQueue like we do in FlinkTimerInterals for the WatermarkHoldState, but I don't see anything wrong with the implementation here.
You likely have a problem in your application code, i.e. you set a timer output timestamp which holds back the watermark but your fire timestamp has not been reached by the watermark yet. Please investigate that first. Also note #12531 which was a bug in the Python SDK.
replies.author: mxm

timeline.message: [BEAM-10691] change PriorityQueue to TreeMultiset for keeping track of timer output timestamps
[BEAM-10691] change PriorityQueue to TreeMultiset for keeping track of timer output timestamps

timeline.bodyText:
We could also consider making this even more efficient by using a TreeMap<Long, Integer> where the key is the output timestamp and the value the number of timers which have set it, similar to how it's done in FlinkStateInternals for the watermark holds.
Further, we could remove outputTimestamps entirely and simply use stateInternals.addWatermarkHoldUsage(output_timestamp) and stateInternals.removeWatermarkHoldUsage(output_timestamp).
timeline.author: mxm

replies.bodyText: I don't know the internal details of TreeMultiset, but I'd suppose it to be pretty much the same as Map<Long, Integer> in terms of performance. Removing the outputTimestamps entirely seems to be the best option. I'll try that and let you know.
replies.author: je-ik

replies.bodyText: Maybe we could replace the TreeMap<Long, Integer> with the TreeMultiset?
replies.author: je-ik

replies.bodyText: Why would we do this? TreeMap<Long, Integer> seems like the better data structure because it stores the data compacted.
replies.author: mxm

replies.bodyText: TreeMultiset does the same. And saves some code and performance, the value is stored as array of length 1 and thus adding an already existing item to the set is just get() and in-place increment, while the TreeMap must do get & replace. I think the biggest argument here is that the code is more readable, though. I'll update the PR in a sec, so that you can see.
replies.author: je-ik

replies.bodyText: Wasn't familiar with the internals of TreeMultiSet but if that's the case, it sounds excellent! :)
replies.author: mxm
